body: Native code was reviewed and accepted, so this feature is now available in libps. Now we need monad to use the appropriate code.  Update  GetCPInfo is  currently  only used by the function, IsSingleByteCharacterSystem  . However, this question is always answerable on Linux, as false, because only UTF 8 is supported on Linux  which is not an SBCS . So rather than deal with implementing the cross platform abstractions necessary to call our native function over Windows, we just answer the question directly.  Since that was the only place GetCPInfo was used, unless there's a compelling reason to leave it as a native call, we should remove it from libps.  VSO create date - 9/17/2015 9:30:00     VSO closed date - 9/17/2015 15:55:00
title: [monad]: Remove GetCPInfo

body: get content  Path $testPath  Tail 1 in PSL throws error   Unable to load DLL 'api ms win core localization l1 2 1.dll.  this dll is used in String.Format  Pic   also linked     this error appears to be  line 205 in monad src command management GetContenCommand.cs.  The issue seems tied to an exception being thrown    ErrorRecord is part of System.Management.Automation namespace.    So what was happening is that  for some reason  the function IsSingleByteCharacterSet   was being called. This normally depends on GetCPInfo, but while I was attempting to integrate it in a cross platform manner, I realized that, on Linux, we do not even need to call it to answer this question. We support only UTF 8 on Linux, which is definitively not an SBCS.  VSO create date - 9/15/2015 19:12:00     VSO closed date - 9/17/2015 12:53:00

body: PowerShell profiles have been enabled in HostUtilities and used by our custom host.   This will also allow us to fix #190  Config files in powershell usually reside in the Powershell directory, and are called 'powershell profiles'.  The environment variable $PROFILE in windows will lead you to your own PS Profile in windows.  Mine is located in   PS C  Users v zafolw> $PROFILE C  Users v zafolw Documents WindowsPowerShell Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1  This might by blocked by CorePS, as they have  maybe  not yet implemented profiles.  *\* main.cs host could source this, and then add it to the list of commands scripts during startup, like it does with the prompt and the    expansion currently  Profiles in powershell are implemented in  monad src engine hostifaces HostUtilities.cs, which makes calls to Environment.SpecialFolder.Personal  an enum in Environment.cs, which relies on native Win32 calls.  The logic could be put in the Platform class inside CorePsPlatform inside Platform.NonWindowsGetFolderPath    a method to find special folders.  VSO create date - 9/3/2015 16:39:00     VSO closed date - 11/5/2015 9:39:00

body: It is not currently possible to update CoreCLR as they are removing SecureString, which means that Process.Start   is changing, which breaks PowerShell. Mike Richmond is getting us in the loop for when CorePS gets updated to support the CoreCLR updates.  We need to find out from CorePS how they get CoreCLR, and so which version they're using. If it contains our patch, upgrade directly. Otherwise ask for them to update.  I've pulled in the Linux equivalent of the ProjectK runtime assemblies that CorePS just updated to, located here  And the exact reference assemblies they're using   Going to meet with Wes from CoreCLR soon to get better insights into how this all ties together. ProjectK is essentially the TFS superset of the GitHub hosted CoreCLR. We would prefer to use the latter but the CorePS team uses the former, and we can't afford to continue to try nightlies.  Also, there's a DNVM  DotNet Version Manager  now available for Windows, Linux, and OS X. Dongbo and are looking into switching to it.  I'm currently blocked on updating the custom Makefile used to generate the CorePSTypeCatalog. I'm hoping a clean build of PowerShell on Windows will give me the generated file that I need, as the sources indicate it is clearly generated. Also waiting to hear from Dongbo about this. Failing that, I'll contact Peter.  The custom Makefile thing was solved.  Currently blocked on mismatched assemblies and references. Learning how to build them ourselves so we can get a matching set.  VSO create date - 8/28/2015 11:25:00     VSO closed date - 10/7/2015 11:12:00
title: Repin CoreCLR

title: Support New-Symlink

body: $ . build.sh make prepare rm  rf buildtemp System.Reflection.Metadata.\* buildtemp System.Collections.Immutable.\* buildtemp Microsoft.Net.ToolsetCompilers.\* buildtemp nuget.exe cp .. src monad ext nuget nuget.exe buildtemp nuget.exe cd buildtemp && mono nuget.exe install  Version 1.0.21 System.Reflection.Metadata Attempting to gather dependencies information for package 'System.Reflection.Metadata.1.0.21' with respect to project ' opt monad scripts buildtemp', targeting 'Any,Version=v0.0'  This is due to NuGet 3 being totally broken. Explicitly adding both the  Source and  Version flags fixes it for the current Docker image.  VSO create date - 8/5/2015 16:51:00     VSO closed date - 8/11/2015 9:29:00
title: Fix make prepare on Docker

body: Per #140,  ConvertTo From Json cmdlets fail because they require System.Web.Extensions and attempt to load them at runtime   System.Reflection.Assembly.Load  System.Web.Extensions, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35  ;  CoreCLR does not have System.Web.Extensions support.  This also needs the .NET  Extended Profile,  however it's irrelevant since it would apply only if we were using the .NET Framework directly, and not CoreCLR.  Per David Fowler    That json serializer is pretty terrible. We recommend people use something like json.net instead  which by the way is what mvc uses    It does not sound like CoreCLR now PS will enable this for us, so we may have to do without. I would advise against bundling JSON.NET as it's third party, but it has an agreeable license and this could be done.  CorePS itself doesn't have these.  VSO create date - 8/4/2015 15:39:00
title: [BLOCKED by CorePS] Fix ConvertTo/From-Json

title: create repo servers for PowerShell Linux packages for all supported platforms

body: The goal of this work item is to create universal binary build that can be used for all supported platforms  This is the list of supported distributions for v1   ? CentOS 6 and 7   x86 x64   ? DebianGNU Linux 6 and 7  x86 x64   ? Oracle Linux 6 and 7  x86 x64   ? Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 6 and 7  x86 x64   ? SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 11 and 12  x86 x64   ? Ubuntu Server 12.04 LTS and 14.04 LTS  x86 x64   Other unix based platforms will be considered in architecture where possible, but are otherwise a non goal.  The focus will be on 64 bit platforms first, with 32 bit platforms being an optional goal for v1.    VSO create date - 8/4/2015 8:06:00
title: Create universal build

body: This needs to be done for all planned platforms   This is the list ofsupported distributions for v1      \*  CentOS 6 and 7       x86 x64     \*  DebianGNU Linux 6 and 7      x86 x64     \*  Oracle Linux 6 and 7      x86 x64     \*  Red Hat Enterprise Linux     Server 6 and 7  x86 x64     \*  SUSE Linux Enterprise Server     11 and 12  x86 x64     \*  Ubuntu Server 12.04 LTS and     14.04 LTS  x86 x64    Other unix basedplatforms will be considered in architecture where possible, but are otherwisea non goal.  The focus will be on64 bit platforms first, with 32 bit platforms being an optional goal for v1.  These targets are hilarious. .NET Core supports Ubuntu 14.04. We depend on .NET Core. Therefore we support Ubuntu 14.04.   VSO create date - 8/4/2015 8:05:00
title: Create Linux packages from build artifacts
